Children will love its timeless tasty goodness. Imagine when you were a kid begging for Mommy to get you a Snickers bar! Just think of how your little children will beg mercy for you after one viewing! The way the children are punished seems strange for those who liked to enjoy going on a delightful journey into the sugary unknown. I guess it means "that's life!". Probably the most amazing, yet odd fantasy movie I've watched, but it sure tastes good! The DVD version would be much more tasty....and more fattening!!!

Review title: Amusing and intelligent and just a lot of fun!
Review_body: I recently watched this movie again, many years after it was released. It really has stood the test of time. A lot of creativity went into the production. The acting is great, and the caricatured characters and "moral lessons" very amusing. The use of vibrant colors within the Wonka factory creates a true fantasy land contrasting with the drab surrounding city. And of course there's the nice Dickensian Charlie character...Not sure what to say about the Oompa Loompas. One might consider the use of them in the factory as morally dubious. Are they not slaves? Willy Wonka explains that he has saved them from the depredation rampant in their homeland, where they are in constant danger by wild animals (or something along those lines). So it's supposed to be okay for them to live 24/7 at the factory and work day in and and day out. Question: couldn't they also lead normal lives in the city itself, where none of their natural predators live? At least I did not see any of them running around... For heaven's sake, self-styled moral sage Wonka does not need to keep them trapped at the factory! How would these orange-skinned dwarfs fare amidst ordinary human beings? Unclear.Given the undeniable quality of this movie, I have to ask: why was it remade, when the original version was so good and seems just as modern today? Of course, that's a question I always ask about misguided attempts to create "improved" versions of already classic films. Could it be a sign of megalomania on the part of the later director and cast?

Review title: A wonderful movie for the whole family to watch again and again
Review_body: Mel Stuart's Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory (in which the novel was really called Charlie and the chocolate factory) is arguably one of the greatest family movies ever made along with the Harry Potter franchise, Lord of the Rings trilogy, Bedtime Stories (2008),Home Alone, (1990), A Christmas Story, It's a Wonderful Life, and some of John Hughes' greatest films, as well as Matilda (which was based on a Roald Dahl novel). Some people who may have seen at least one of the film adaptations of Roald Dahl's novels do not get why he treasured children's stories very much, and I was very curious myself without even thinking about it until I saw the film adaptation of Matilda (1996) which was directed by Danny DeVito got my questions answered, and that answer was that not only children can be entertained by his work but teenagers and adults as well. But while I was watching this film which also happened to be based on a Roald Dahl novel made me love the magic of kids movies a lot more than I have before, the film tells the story of an poor boy named Charlie (played by Peter Ostrum) who after school works as a paperboy in order to support his family mortgage, and gets involved in a golden ticket contest for five people and each of the winners gets to bring one family member as well as Willy Wonka (played by Gene Wilder)himself. After everyone around the globe finds out about the contest it ends up to be a race against time to see who five people really are going to be and we find out about each one approximately a few minutes apart from one another (though I won't get too in depth with the film's story). the film is also an excellent way of getting to know Charlie who was the last of the 5 winners in the contest and after all of the five winners were confirmed Charlie brings his grandfather (played by Academy Award winner Jack Albertson), the film also has an excellent supporting cast which includes Julie Dawn Cole as the spoiled brat Veruca Salt, Roy Kinnear as Veruca's Alfred Pennyworth type father who follows every father's philosophy in order to make their own lives as well as their children's lives a whole lot easier is to be happier all the time and he does in the most feminine type of way, Denise Nickerson as Violet who is a huge gum chewer and ironically ends up being one of the contest winners even though she doesn't really eat chocolate, Leonard Stone in a great father like performance as Violet's father (and obviously he is much more manly than Veruca's father), Michael Ollner as the very disobedient and overweight Augustus Gloop, and Ursula Reit as Augustus's mother. Another thing that I noticed while watching this film was that it blends the two genres of both comedy and musical together of which that to me was really neat. This movie is a film that is committed to it's story, characters, and humor that Roald Dahl put into his 1964 novel, this is one of the best movies of 1971 as well as one of the best movies of the 1970s.

"If you want to view paradise, simply look around and view it." Willy Wonka & The Chocolate Factory is one of the best children films of all-time. The characters, you all have to adore, even if their annoying or not. The film is about a boy who finds a golden ticket in a Willy Wonka chocolate bar and heads off to see the Willy Wonka factory with his grandpa and other people. Gene Wilder was great as Willy Wonka and his performance was quite funny and actually kind of weird. The kids were all great especially Augustus Gloop, he was hilarious. Overall, Willy Wonka & The Chocolate Factory is a classic and should be viewed by everyone.Hedeen's Oulook: 9/10 ***+ A-

The author, Roald Dahl, has served as a pool of stories filled with fantasy, wacky but likable characters, and morals fit for children. This is the movie adaptation of one of his stories, very much in the mold of an "Alice in Wonderland", the protagonist being a child and all the candor he manifests, and this film is further testament to the 'Peter Pan' myth that within us lives forever a child, full of a purity and enthusiasm that never die. Willy Wonka is superbly interpreted by Gene Wilder here, and it should be said all the children actors play their roles very well too. Especially, I thought, the little Veruca Salt. The song scenes are very good, the Oompa Loompa song being an absolute cinema classic that'll ring in people's heads til they die. The dialog is excellent, every Wonka line being somehow symbolic or having double meaning. Overall this film is an ode to humanity, principle, but also to the strange: don't be afraid to show your difference, even if it scares some. The boat scene for example, a metaphor of the stranger dimension of eccentric experimentation. Excellent watch.

Review title: "Time is a precious thing, never waste it."
Review_body: Mel Stuart took viewers to a world of pure imagination in his 1971 feature Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory. In perhaps his most well-known role, Gene Wilder as the eccentric candy man looking to pass on his chocolate legacy created a brilliant film adaptation of the book, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory by Roald Dahl. Wilder's exquisite performance proved he could command an entire film, despite him only being in the film's second half. A fun family experience, Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory spans generations to bring pure imagination to all ages.Willy Wonka (Gene Wilder), candy extraordinaire is well known for being a recluse in his chocolate factory. Fearing intrusion, he has locked himself in his factory free to invent and produce the best chocolate the world has known without threat. When word breaks that Willy Wonka will open his factory to 5 winners of golden tickets hidden in his chocolate bars, the world is stunned as they all scatter, ravishing his bars to gain entry into his elusive chocolate paradise. Young Charlie Bucket (Peter Ostrum) of meager means, believes that he has to win a golden ticket because he wants the prize more than anyone else does. After all 5 of the golden tickets are discovered, Charlie cries in his room devastated to have missed out on meeting the man his grandfather always told him stories about. To console himself, Charlie treats himself to a Wonka bar after he finds some money in the street. To his surprise, just after he buys the bar, the news breaks that the fifth golden ticket was a fake. With the last shred of hope in him, Charlie opens his bar to find a glimmer of gold around his candy bar. After racing home to tell his family the good news, Charlie, and Grandpa Joe (Jack Albertson) prepare for their trip to the chocolate factory the next day. Wearing a purple velvet coat, Willy Wonka greets the guests to his factory walking with a cane, that he gets stuck in a brick and falls forward in a fantastic somersault. From this point on, Willy Wonka's credibility is questioned as he leads the children and their families through his factory where there are "little surprises around every turn". Some of those surprises result in removal of the children from the factory until only Charlie is left to discover Willy Wonka's motives for opening his chocolate paradise. Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory is a sincere treat for children and parents alike. A fun moral movie that is never too overt with its message, Willy Wonka is an experience to have as often as possible. The worst part of this movie is waiting the 47 minutes of well-done build-up before we actually get to see Willy Wonka. Gene Wilder is fantastic in the role of the mysterious peculiar owner of the candy empire. He has his perfect moments of emotion, which he is often accused of overdoing the yelling--a criticism I find unfounded. I read that he had to fight to have his opening scene filmed the way that made it into the movie, with his walking being aided by a cane. It was a good decision on behalf of Mel Stuart to relent and film it this way, because, from that moment on, you never knew what Mr. Wonka was capable of, nor did you understand his motives. This mystery was necessary to the story, and a bit of the premise the film depends on upon would have been lost without it. This bit of trivia just further goes to support what an acting genius Gene Wilder is.Always do as your told, follow rules and authority, adults are looking out for your best interests are the easy messages to take away from this film. Upon closer inspection, however, one can see that the adults are no better equipped to look after themselves than their children are. It is an adult that is trying to steal from Mr. Wonka, and get the kids to steal his secrets, it is the adults that are encouraging their kids to do Slugworth's bidding, and it is the adults who find it difficult to resist the temptations around them. Maybe the bigger message is that there's a little childlike wonder left in all of us, as long as we don't try to hard to extinguish it. The adults become just as enchanted as the children when they first enter Mr. Wonka's brilliant candy-filled world. Maybe, just maybe, the underlying message is that we all advance in age as we make it through life, but if we are careful, we never have to grow up. I stick with that message, Willy Wonka doesn't live too bad of a life, after all.
A magical, inventive, sweet-filled and childhood film. Many generation have watched this. The second one they made I have erased from my memory.

Review title: "There is no life I know to compare with pure imagination"
Review_body: This entire movie is just so magical. Roald Dahl, the author of the book on which the film is based, is known the world over for being one of the most prolific children's book writers, but many don't realize that the books aren't just appealing to children. James and The Giant Peach, Danny the Champion of the World, The Witches, and Willy Wonka are all well written stories for the most part, and so movie adaptations feeding off their success started to predictably appear. Out of all of Dahl's books to be turned into movies, this one is without a doubt the most famous, and it's not hard to see why. The movie's plot is about the titular Willy Wonka who owns a mysterious chocolate factory that nobody can have access to. Soon, Wonka announces that there is a contest that involves people buying his chocolate bars and finding golden tickets hidden inside. The winner receives a tour of his strange factory, but since there are only 5 tickets in the entire world, it's way easier said than done. A modest boy named Charlie is the story's unlikely protagonist, he is humble enough to not let the temptation of finding a golden ticket control his life. He doesn't expect to find one, and his family is much more important to him than a bunch of candy. As time goes by, the golden tickets start getting discovered by lucky children from various locations around the world, but the kids who win are all spoiled and don't really deserve them. A gluttonous German kid named Augustus is the first winner, followed by Veruca Salt, Violet Beauregarde, and Mike Teevee. Finally, Charlie manages by pure luck to find a ticket after the original fifth winner is proved to be a fake. Out of all the children who win, Charlie is the only decent one that doesn't have a snarky, in-your-face attitude, and it makes the audience sympathize with him. The rest of the movie involves Charlie being taken on a tour (along with the other children) of Wonka's factory while he is chaperoned by his formerly bedridden grandfather. Wonka shows them all kinds of strange candy related things, from waterfalls made of melted chocolate to drinks that allow the consumer to float. There's a shocking false ending where Charlie, as the only remaining member of the tour after all the other kids have been eliminated, asks Wonka about the promised lifetime supply of chocolate, and Wonka tells him he's not getting any as he "broke the rules" by stealing the lifting drinks. Charlie's grandfather suggests to Charlie he should get even with Wonka by giving the recipes for some of his secret Candy to his adversary Slugworth, but Charlie returns the gobstopper to Wonka instead. As it turns out, this whole part was just a test of morals that only Charlie was decent enough to pass, and Wonka tells Charlie that his family now has legal ownership over his factory. The performances in this movie are all amazing, especially Wilder's, and he was without a doubt the best Willy Wonka ever. Also an interesting note about this movie, the part at the end where Wonka yells at Charlie for violating the rules is actually non-rehearsed, and Charlie didn't know Gene was going to yell at him. This allowed the filmmakers to get his real reaction.

Review title: Held from perfection by changes from the source material...
Review_body: I would lie if I told you I didn't enjoy watching this movie. It has wonderful music, acting and a lot of charm! However, I had some criticism and later I compared it to stuff that critics at the time said and I must say I agree with them. There is no overly memorable songs, Gene Wilder completely steals the show (which is good because his performance is fantastic, but bad because Charlie is not in the focus, hence the changed name of the movie compared to the book) and stuff is added/changed for no reason. That doesn't mean this is a bad movie and it is most certainly better than Burton's version in which Wonka acts like a schizophrenic, but it pales when being compared to the masterpiece like "The Wizard of Oz" (some stuff are added/changed here too, but the dynamic of the movie remains stable throughout the whole deal) which is also a musical based on a book for children. All in all, I give the movie 8/10! It's still a wonderful movie, but the fans of the book will notice the difference and will probably be somewhat displeased, while the rest won't even notice, and for them I say 10/10! :)

Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory was the first feature length film adapted from one of Roald Dahl's books. Since it's release in 1971, it's become a cult classic, and is widely appreciated by children and adults alike.It is also a film I've studied in great detail. Observed from every angle. I'm not really sure why. It's almost as if there' a mystery at the heart of it I want to crack. Why is it so popular? Why does it seem so effortlessly enjoyable? Roald Dahl officially hated the film when it was finished. He thought it strayed too far from the book and was not menacing enough. Personally I disagree. I think it recaptures perfectly what made the book so engaging. Granted it didn't need to alter the title, but it's still a fantastic yarn and continues to entertain even today.The film made the wise choice of properly introducing the character of Willy Wonka at least 40 minutes in. Which is also when we see the Chocolate Factory itself. It builds the anticipation steadily. Beforehand, we meet the plucky young Charlie (Peter Ostrum), and the rest of his obnoxious companions who all gradually find the five Golden Tickets.There are quite a few people who think Willy Wonka is slow to start. I've never felt that way. I enjoy every scene before we get to the factory. There are some marvellously funny sequences, such as Charlie's pompous schoolteacher, Veruca's hilarious petulance, and the reactions of people going mad searching for the Golden Tickets. There is a hidden subtext here about the greed that overwhelms people, and Charlie gets a Ticket without really looking. Because he truly deserves one, where these other people don't.The film also benefits from excellent direction from Mel Stuart. We meet each one of the horrible children in brief vignettes, and we already learn enough about them to side with Charlie, and pray they'll get what they deserve. The one major difference between the film and the book is an added subplot concerning the Everlasting Gobstopper. A rival of Wonka's, Slugworth, approaches each one of the children, and offers large sums of money in exchange for the secret recipe. I thought this was a nice touch because it adds a little ambiguity to Charlie's character, and is a departure from his squeaky clean image in the book.It's at this point we meet the person everyone has been dying to see. Willy Wonka. Gene Wilder was an interesting choice, and proves to be a total revelation. Wilder is not always one of the easiest actors in the world to watch, because of his annoying habit of screaming things out endlessly. But from his memorable first appearance walking slowly with a limp to doing a somersault, his dynamic energy is instantly engaging because it's so carefully precise. And when he does go over the top, it's entirely in character. Willy Wonka still remains Gene Wilder's finest hour.In regards to the chocolate factory, I still believe it's an astonishing array of colourful dimensions, bizarre confections and beautiful sights. There's everything here from chocolate waterfalls, candy striped meadows and sweet inventing rooms. All populated by the Oompa-Loopas, little dwarfs who carefully maintain the factory.Underneath the sugary sweet veneer, there is an undeniably sinister aftertaste. Each one of the kids disappears through their own selfishness and greed, and in another departure from the book, where we saw them at the end, here we don't. We never do find out what happens to them, especially with oblique references from Wonka such as boilers, furnaces, taffy pullers and juicers. Wonka is hilariously unconcerned with their dilemmas, which gives the film considerable kick as a cautionary tale without ever becoming too preachy.Despite the bizarre fates that befall them, this is undeniably Wonka's show all the way. He is completely in control, and it's always a wonder listening to him come out with philosophies, tactics for boosting his products, and half-hearted warnings. With a chocolate coloured hat, chocolate wrapper coloured coat, a twinkle in his eye and a spring in his step, Wilder turns Wonka into a fully rounded character who keeps the audience captive. He's also got a fine singing voice to boot.As events draw to a close, it's quite shocking when Charlie nearly loses out on the grand prize through a careless mistake. Naturally he convinces Wonka of his worth, but the fact that he nearly didn't only shows how ambiguous Wonka is. It all ends nicely in the Wonkavator, with Charlie inheriting the empire, and ensuring a new life for his poverty-stricken family.Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory still remains the best of the Roald Dahl screen interpretations, and is a template of the perfect children's film. One that appeals to the child in all of us, but still touches base with the adult so it never becomes patronising. Tim Burton's remake was a respectful incarnation, and succeeds on it's own merits, but the original still resonates with audiences as the classic it has become, and deserves to be.

Review title: Willie Wonka and the Creepy Oompa Loompas
Review_body: No matter how many times I have watched this tape, I love it more and more.Except the Oompa Loompas.I have nothing against little people, but the Oompa Loompas always creep me out, with their weird looks and bursting into song (Oompa Loompa doompade doo/I've got another puzzle for you), just creep me out!Otherwise, I like the film (I never read the book, but I've heard that it doesn't stick too close to it). The kids (Charlie excluded), are the most obnoxious bunch on the face of the planet (I've always wanted to slap Veruca Salt in the face!). Charlie is your typical poor-boy-with-a-good-heart (And wonderfully played by Peter Ostrum), with a mother and grandparents. Winner of a golden ticket along with 4 other kids, he gets to go on a magical tour of Willie Wonka's Chocolate Factory. Wonka (Gene Wilder, who seems to enjoy torturing the kids).The film still holds up over 30 years later and I still love the ending.But still...Those DAMN OOMPA LOOMPAS!!!!

Review title: The Best Movie Adaption To The Book!
Review_body: This movie is the best version of the book, it not only ages well but its such an accurate description to some lines from the book in the movie, its just portrayed in such a great way. No disrespect to Johnny Depp as he is a national treasure and his movie was also very good but I have a strong attachment to this version as its the one I gre up watching, wishing I could go to a chocolate factory just like Charlie bucket.I think this was a remarkable movie and if it was possible a sequel could of been amazing, Gene Wilder was an amazing actor, who accomplished quite a lot in his short time acting.I highly recommend this movie to all fans and non fans, its entertaining enough to absolutely anyone.

This is one of my favourite childhood films. It just holds so many memories for me. This is the perfect children's film with music and comedy and, of course, candy.The movie is nothing like the book. It only uses the names and the idea, but it is great as a stand alone film. The songs are catchy and memorable, and Gene Wilder's performance as Wonka is genius. It's a really enjoyable family comedy and there's not a doubt in my mind that it will hold up for many years to come. Another good thing about it is that there's comedy for children and for adults. Everybody can find enjoyment from this movie. The sets are great for a 1970's film, and it really lets you believe that such a place could exist. Really, if you haven't seen this movie yet, go out and rent/buy it. You won't be disappointed.8/10

Review title: This classic story about a good little boy and a bizarre candymaker is a must see for parents
Review_body: Gene Wilder turns in a wonderfully eerie performance as our eccentric and knowing host conducting the tour of the mysterious Wonka Chocolate Factory, capturing a quirky but gentle nature all the while serving just deserts! While Charlie (Peter Ostrum) is our poor boy hero who can't carry a tune, his four golden ticket counterparts are sadistically spoiled and comically obnoxious and none better than Veruca Salt (Julie Dawn Cole). We see the brats of the world groomed to be so by discipline-less and over indulgent parents. The psychedelic boat ride and poem was as macabre as they come. This was a movie musical whose purpose was to promote a candy bar and today still holds an enlightening charm without cavities!

Review title: A great film, but a pretty poor adaptation
Review_body: Now before we start, I want to make one thing perfectly clear. I love this movie, I love it, this is one of the films I watched all the time as a kid. It was great when I was a kid, and it's still great now. However, this movie could be one of the weakest book to film adaptations ever made. Granted I haven't read every book and read every movie, but I have read the book "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory," and yes it does have the same plot and moral, but there are so many changes made.OK, the reason I love this film is because of a few things. The actors are great, every child fits the role perfectly. And Gene Wilder IS Willy Wonka. The songs are super catchy, and the special effects are outstanding. This film is over forty years old, and it still looks good. And it has a great sense of imagination, always being creative with the names of the candies.However it doesn't work well as an adaptation, they were squirrels in the book, the Slugworth guy was only in a short sentence, they used a glass elevator right after veruca. The Wonka Wash didn't exist. They were allowed to bring two guests. Charlie's dad wasn't dead. And they added songs for no reason.Remember, I love this movie, it's one of my most nostalgic movies, but it isn't that great of an adaptation. If you want a closer version to the book, watch Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. But I do recommend this movie.

Gene wilder demanded that the scene where he is first introduced be the way that it be or he wouldn't do the movie. The first time you see him on screen is also the first time any of the cast met him. He said after that scene no one would know if he was lying or telling the truth. Another real moment is the cast walking into the candy room. None of them had seen it up to that point so you're seeing genuine reactions. It's magic like that that makes this movie all the more great.

This brilliant children's classic has all of the "stuff" that great films are made of. The story centers around the mysterious Mr. Wonka, who own's the worlds most magnificent chocolate and candy factory. Mr. Wonka's famous candy bars are especially desirable these days, because 5 of them have a "golden ticket", the winners of which will be guests of honor and receive a tour of the chocolate factory, along with wonderful prizes.The entire world is watching via TV and everyone follows the news of who is winning the golden tickets. Our hero, poor boy Charlie is the most deserving to win one of the tickets, and he does! The magical tour of the factory is a treat to watch. Then there are the wonderful songs, highlighted by "The Candy Man", which 2 years later became a #1 hit for Sammy Davis Jr.This is a gem of a family movie. Only "The Wizard of Oz" could beat this one to the top of anyone's favorites list. Kids of all ages will treasure "Willy Wonka & The Chocolate Factory" for generations yet unknown!

Review title: Still one of the best kids films ever made
Review_body: Willie Wonka is the crazed solitary genius who lives in a mega-chocolate factory on the hill, where nobody has ever been. When he issues golden tickets to visit his factory, poor but dreamy boy Charlie is among the winners, and visits Wonka's magical world...Dahl apparently hated this version of his generation-transcending tale of greed and gluttony in a magical candy land. Viewers need not be alarmed however: a book is a book and a film is a film and each should be its own beast, and authors are often the least people who should tell how the film version should be (to note: every Stephen King novel adapted by King has been an artistic failure, when the adaptations he disliked - mainly Shinning - were great), and this is a case study of the phenomenon.Who better than Gene Wilder to play the manic, reclusive and unhinged Willie Wonka? He bravely carries the whole film on his shoulders and is assisted by a very competent young cast. The general tone is just as wonderful, as, unlike the newer version, things aren't spelled out for us (the factory's logic, Wonka's origins), because the film trust children to understand its internal logic, a brave and fulfilling move that is too rarely seen in today's film output (and probably earned the film some scorn from bewildered parents, which would explain its initial box-office failure).This version is the one to see, and Gene Wilder's ambivalent psychopath soars beyond Johnny Depp's gloomy creation. Unlike Tim Burton's mismatched mess, this world brims with colors, the Umpalumpas are a touch sinister and there is that touch of underlying darkness (the demented boat ride). That this gem's ratings have gone up since Burton's misguided version was released only attest further to its staying power and greatness.So, in fewer words, let go of your adult arrogance, allow yourself to be a child again, and dive into Willie Wonka's magical world. You're in for a rare thrill!

Review title: When you watch this film creation, you will find yourself in a world of pure imagination!
Review_body: "Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory" (1971), I remember the very first time I saw this movie as a child. To this day, I'm still blown away with how great this film is. It has found a spot on my list of my top 10 all-time favorite family films. It has a perfect story, perfect acting, perfect sets/locations, perfect special effects, and of course a perfect soundtrack to tie it together. The storyline is based off the book "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory", written by Roald Dahl. Originally, the film script was going to be written entirely by Roald Dahl himself, along with David Seltzer. However, since Roald Dahl failed to meet deadlines, David Seltzer did some rewrites to the script and the story was changed. Now, in most cases, changing an original story from a book for cinema standards can make or break it. However, in the case of this movie, the changes made the plot line in the movie are a good thing. It made the film that much more entertaining than the original novel. Don't get me wrong, I still love the original book. It's a lot of fun to read! Here's something that might shock you, Roald Dahl hated this movie adaptation of his book so much that he disowned it! I can understand his anger of his book being changed. If you were in his shoes, you would probably feel upset too! But, for our benefit, the movie came out fantastic and the storyline keeps you hooked from beginning to end. Sorry, Roald Dahl..... I really love this film! As for the acting, it is stellar from all of the actors and actresses. The top three standout performances come from the one and only Gene Wilder as Willy Wonka, Peter Ostrum as Charlie Bucket and Jack Albertson as Grandpa Joe. They really make this movie! Gene Wilder is legendary and iconic as Willy Wonka. Peter Ostrum is absolutely phenomenal and charming as Charlie Bucket and Jack Albertson is funny and heartwarming as Grandpa Joe. Here's an interesting bit of history for you. This was the only role that Peter Ostrum played in his acting career. Isn't that something? This was the only time that Peter Ostrum acted in a motion picture. But, what a great performance it was! It's a shame that he didn't pursue acting any further, he had great potential. He is currently a veterinarian, which is still cool. It's what he wants to be, and who are we to deny him? As for the rest of the actors and actresses in this movie, they fire on all cylinders as well and definitely help bring this film to life! All of the sets/locations are perfect and give this film an amazing atmosphere. Of course, my favorite set in this movie has to be the Chocolate Room. Whenever I see a screenshot, or film clip of that room I can immediately pinpoint it to this movie. Talk about an iconic set! All of the rest of the rooms in the factory are just as breathtaking. As for the special effects, they are all very well-done. Some of them can get a bit cheesy at times, but that's what helps to give this movie it's special charm! Finally, the soundtrack written by: Leslie Bricusse, Anthony Newley and Walter Scharf is amazing and helps to tie the whole film together. I could hear any random part of this film score, and know right away that it's from this movie. That's the mark of a phenomenal film score! "Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory" is nothing but cinematic gold for people of all ages. I can watch it over and over again and never get tired of it. Of course, I give this movie 5 out of 5 stars on my scale, which equates to 10 out of 10 IMDB stars. If you haven't seen this film, go watch it, especially if you have kids. You'll make them very happy! I guarantee that they'll love this movie, and you will too. Grab your golden ticket, and prepare for an adventure!

Review title: Sweeter than Charlie and the Chocolate Factory
Review_body: While some may argue that this version of the story is not as faithful to the Roald Dahl book as Tim Burton's recent remake Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, it is still a far better movie.The story of an eccentric candy maker named Willy Wonka (Gene Wilder) who has offered a tour of his very secretive factory along with a life time supply of chocolate to anyone that finds one of the 5 golden tickets hidden inside Wonka Chocolate bars.One young boy Charlie Bucket can hardly afford to buy a single bar but dreams of finding one of the tickets and taking his Grampa Joe (Jack Albertson) with him on the tour.The interior of the candy factory though done on a limited budget and without the benefit of modern CGI was and is awe inspiring, particularly for children. Apparently to achieve the look of wonder on the faces of the children they were not shown this set until filming began.One standout aspect of this film was certainly the music, to this day the songs from the film remain captivating. The film was nominated for an Oscar for Best Music, Scoring Adaptation and Original Song Score. One of songs written for the film was The Candy Man which would become a standard for Sammy Davis Jr.As good as Johnny Depp is as an actor; the role of Willy Wonka was handled more effectively by the very talented Gene Wilder. Unfortunately the Depp portrayal comes across as a bit too creepy.Another aspect of the film where it exceeds the remake is the portrayal of the Oompa Loompa's. Instead of eerie miniature digital recreations of a single actor we have a group of little people including at least one female, and most of whom could not speak English.

For some strang reason, many people like this movie and call it "delightful family fun"... Which part is your favorite, the part where they chop a chicken's head off, or the parts where the children are killed in various ways like you might see in "Nightmare on Elm Street"?  Let us not forget the impish Oompa-loompas, who are forced into slave labor by the totally creepy Willy Wonka, who also makes everyone sign away their souls in a deal-with-the-devil contract at the beginning of the movie.  Someone else compared this movie to "Seven", which is exactly what I was thinking when I watched this movie the other day.  A bunch of bad kids are killed by their "sins".  If this is the kind of movie you consider to be "fun" for kids, you might as well make it a double feature with "A Clockwork Orange".

Review title: Up There With "The Wizard of Oz", And Many Other Children Classics.
Review_body: Pretty much the definitive movie you could watch as a child, and remember fondly as an adult. Roald Dahl's classic book and adaptation is pure gold from beginning to end.Charlie Bucket is a poor kid, who soon competes with every other child in the world to obtain one of five golden tickets into the famous chocolate factory run by the apparently eccentric, but public recluse Willy Wonka. By miraculous odds Charlie gets a ticket, along with four other children who finally enter the factory. From there on, the movie takes on the presence of a proverbial slasher movie, as each child is disposed of through their own greedy faults. Incorporate one of the weirdest tunnels scenes ever committed to film and in all seriousness, it's actually one of the most charming movies ever made.Gene Wilder is the definitive Willy Wonka. Obviously he's still a few years away from Mel Brooks's comedy goldmine, but no one can do what he does in this movie and sell a performance like he can. "Pure Imagination" is one of the all time greatest songs from this musical, and the Oompa Loompa's are parodied to death nowadays because they're so darn good.Out of all his stories, this remains my favourite of Roald Dahl's work. Though it may shy away a little from it's source material, this movie blends fantasy, adventure and dark humour perfectly. The factory is so incredibly detailed, and I heard that the chocolate river was two feet deep and became stagnant almost immediately (Poor Augustus).Final Verdict: Another children's timeless classic. 10/10.

SPOILERSLike I said before, I liked Charlie and the Chocolate Factory a little bit better, but this is still a great musical film. It has very memorable songs that everyone loves, well, except for the Oompa-Loompa songs. Speaking of Oompa-Loompas, they are positively creepy. They are orange with white eyebrows. They are just plain disturbing. Anyway, this is a good film. I can't believe Gene Wilder was Willy Wonka. He was great as him, but he normally does Mel Brooks films.I told you the plot in my comment for Charlie. A kid wins a Golden Ticket to go to Willy Wonka's factory and all the other kids are punished. However, the ending is just a bit different. Willy Wonka goes into his office and Charlie gives back his Ever-Lasting Gobstopper. Wonka is delighted and the film ends in the Great-Glass Elevator, which is pretty abrupt. This is also the soda room. Charlie and his grandfather are levitated off the ground until they hit a fan, but they belch to get down.Overall, this is a very fun film to watch. It has great songs, catchy tunes, good acting, and more. Although it may not be very faithful to the novel, it is still great. In the novel it ends with the Great-Glass Elevator crashing into Charlie's house, but int this it ends in the Great-Glass Elevator. Anyway, a lot of people can and will enjoy this 1971 flick. There is one thing I'd like to mention, the boat ride is really bizarre. Anyway, this is a nice film.8/10Recommended Films: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.

With all due respect to the great Johnny Depp. Chocolate Factory was a dud and Johnny Depp is nothing more than Michael Jackson in that film. Sorry Johnny I love you in most of your other movies. In a nutshell, Gene Wilder is the only Willy Wonka that matters. A strong person with vulnerabilities that are better left unrevealed. This film is about virtue, fantasy, and life ... Not necessarily in that order. While it is unfair for me to judge Depp. For hes just following bosses orders. The criticism must stick.
