The lead character of our story is a young boy by the name of Charlie Bucket (played by the talented Peter Ostrum) who lives in a lower-class neighborhood alongside his Grandpa Joe (Jack Albertson) and several other ailing family members. Sweeping into town comes an announcement from behind the doors of a mysterious chocolate factory: five lucky children will have a chance to get a tour of the also mystical Willy Wonka's factory! The chase is on, and all chocolate factories from one end of the street to another are jam-packed of kids wanting to find the lucky golden ticket that holds the "key" to the tour. Before anyone knows what's happened, four kids have got their tickets. Sadly, all of them are spoiled rotten brats. This pattern changes when Charlie finds the final ticket, and he's ecstatic. Bringing along Grandpa Joe, Charlie embarks on the tour with high hopes. What he gets is more than a little unexpected, I'm sure.I can't help but take notice of the amazingly beautiful background that this film is saturated in. Yes, perhaps they are dated, but for a movie that was filmed in the early 1970's, the producers and what not did a superb job of making the whole "fantasy candy land" a reality, and I applaud them sincerely. I actually think it's better that this movie is so old, as it gives it a very surreal aura. I also cannot forget the acting! Throughout the movie I found myself honestly intrigued with every character that was thrown my way. Every actor made their persona as believable as possible, especially Gene Wilder who I have to tip my hat to. I first saw the man in Young Frankenstein, and he never ceases to surprise me with his unbelievable top-botch portrayal of zany characters. His job as Willy Wonka is no exception.Willy Wonka is a part of pop culture, it would seem. It's hard not to notice the effect that it's had on the States. Whether it's constant references to people turning into blueberries, the constant jokes about Oompa Loompa's, the memorable Marilyn Manson video where he imitates one of my favorite scenes in the movie... it all gives more reason to check this movie out. As I said before, this is a total family movie. Not just confined to the age-old "child" or "adult" categories, Willy Wonka crosses the border and becomes a classic that no one will forget any time soon. Check this one out now for good laughs, an intriguingly eccentric story and character line-up, and extraordinary acting to boot.

Review title: Candy for the Eyes and Ears
Review_body: Willy Wonka and The Chocolate Factory is the story of an eccentric owner of a candy company named Willy Wonka (Gene Wilder) who holds a contest to find five golden tickets in his candy bars. Whoever finds them will be allowed to enter his factory. Amongst the winners is an average boy named Charlie. Charlie and others are led by Willy Wonka through a world of imagination and wonder.This is absolutely one of the greatest children's movies ever created. Not only does it please the eyes with its fantasy world full of imagination and vibrant colors, it contains great songs that you will be singing for a weeks to come. Gene Wilder portrays Willy Wonka brilliantly by being crazy and unpredictable. This is a must see for anyone looking for a movie that is both entertaining and fun.

My favorite movie of all time as it just cements as a worthy classic among the greats. It just is a feel good movie that lifts your spirits and dears you to dream of a world of pure imagination. Willy Wonka is arguably one of the best characters in film history as Gene Wilder plays him to perfection and was truly sad to see him past in 2016. A beautifully stunning film with set pieces good enough to eat and music so delightful it makes you want to cry. I don't really care if Roald Dahl hated it, I loved it and makes up for that empty remake Charlie and the Chocolate Factory which is accurate to the source material but not appealing to the original. I believe Gene Wilder should have been at least nominated for an Oscar of his portrayal of the candy maker.Overall if you haven't seen this film, you will be living in bland world until you take a golden ticket tour into Wonka's chocolate factory. Cinema Perfection in one film. Could not recommended it enough. A++++++++

Review title: For the young and young at heart
Review_body: In all of Gene Wilder's smart remarks and catchy tunes, he is simply saying "Use your imagination."  No movie could exemplify this statement better than this one.  For the young and young at heart, chocolate lover or not, anyone with a heart could enjoy this movie.  From the oompa loompas to the TV that can shrink candy bars, Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory has an intense imagination embedded in the dream of a little boy that could be anything if he simply believed that he could be anything he wanted.  A heart-warming movie with heart-warming performances that definitely deserves a 10!

Review title: Imagination can be one's greatest ally in this fight called life, and it comes in the form of "Willy Wonka and The Chocolate Factory".
Review_body:
This movie does'nt even deserved to be called as low as a movie.  Yeah, him trying to find the ticket might be a somewhat tedious process, but the changing of scenes here and there keep you going, wanting to see more.  And it starts out with a great song, and a great actor, and an overall great scene.  It starts off as a masterpiece, and just when you think it might be dragging along...BOOM!  Out comes another great song/scene.
Then, the Chocolate Factory itself...
Let you imagination run wild!  "Surprises around every corner but nothing dangerous!".  The cast, man.  A great cast if ever one has seen one.  They all fit their part perfectly.  Violet was the least believable one, but even she was TOTALLY believable.  Get my point?  The song, the very first song sung by Willy Wonka, has to be the greatest movie song ever, and be the greatest scene ever, esp. what he does at the end of it. It's so cool, and you never expect it.  Any of it, through out the whole movie.  The monologue/song in the boat, the umpa loompas, the many, MANY changing expressions of Willy Wonka.    Man.  Gene Wilder was so great in this movie, words cannot describe him.  Want to just forget about everything?  Forget about your worries, your doubts(were have I heard that before), your fears? Just let it all go?  Then watch this movie.  Imagination can be a one's greatest tool in this fight called life, and it comes in one form "Willy Wonka and The Chocolate Factory".Describing how great this movie is and why would take forever. Just rest assured that if you ever hear about this movie coming on the TV or see it at a video store, that you can watch it, and then want to watch it again...and again...and again...

Review title: My favorite movie of all time, forever
Review_body: This winter I went into a wave of nostalgia, and Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory was the biggest thing from my childhood that I remembered and loved. This is undoubtably my most favorite movie of all time, forever. Despite all of the shallow comments by some saying this movie is 'horrible' and 'disturbing' I grew up on this movie and loved it. So did my friends, and my family. To this day if I go out and wear my shirt that has the Wonka logo on it (yes, there is one ^_^) I get a barrage of comments on how that's their favorite childhood movie. It remains a treasured childhood memory to this day for me as well. As a child, I was captivated by it's colorfulness, the thought of so much candy, and by the humorous characters. Today, I'm captivated by it's true depth and moral meaning, and the depth of the characters. The kids are hilarious because we can all relate to their faults and hate brats. Charlie is wonderful because we always root for the underdog. The Oompa Loompas are a subltly humorous and wise touch, and my all-time favorite, Willy Wonka, is a mix of charming and eccentric, funny yet sarcastic, and gentle yet harshly wise. To this day he remains my favorite and most inspirational movie character. Gene Wilder did a completely fantastic job as the eccentric candyman- they couldn't have picked a better person to display Wonka's wonderful wackiness. ("If the good Lord had intended us to walk, he wouldn't have invented roller skates!")All in all, definitely give this movie a try. I wholeheartedly agree with someone who wrote not to listen to the people who say this movie is 'bad' or 'disturbing.' I'm not bashing those who don't like the movie, but those who make ridiculous assumptions about it. This movie, despite it's little bits of intenseness does teach an important lesson on where greed will get you and what a kind-heart will ultimately win you- you just can't be too shallow with it or you'll miss it. (And no, the children don't die when they fall into their own traps. At the end Wonka assures Charlie that they'll be perfectly restored to their old selves, but perhaps a bit 'wiser for the wear.') When you watch, don't think too hard or criticize, just sit back and enjoy a trip through Pure Imagination!

Review title: True to the spirit if not the book. Lasts the test of time.
Review_body: Truly delightful.Perhaps it's too much to expect that a boy who physically captures Charlie Bucket should also have a singing voice. We might, however, hope for his shortcomings to be concealed by a better voice than Jack Albertson's.Still, neither flaw can detract from this film's truly original and entertaining score. Songs and story that continue to last the test of time.Likewise, Gene Wilder's eccentric and mischievous Wonka is a joy to watch. The true gems, however, are the subtle interactions of the veteran actors portraying family, particular Mr. Salt.Morals and magic abound, captured with such eloquence by Wonka himself with the wisdom, "We are the music makers and we are the dreamers of the dreams."

Review title: How can they re-make this film?
Review_body: This 1971 children's film is a classic. It's funny, fun, mysterious, and even a little scary. The performances are wonderful, the music is timeless, and it is quite a good rendition of the classic book by Roald Dahl, granted Mr. Dahl wrote the screenplay. Now a re-make of the classic film is slated to be shot. I find this hard to believe-- just like re-making Psycho-- what is the point? Re-making films in the era of video and DVD seems silly. In the earlier days of films, the older versions were not readily available for the public, so it seemed fine to re- introduce the world to the stories, but now I just don't understand the point in re- making films that are classics. The new one may be a fine rendition-- I have faith that Johnny Depp is fully capable of playing a wonderful Willy Wonka, but it's a role that I think was already extremely well portrayed by Gene Wilder. What a magical movie this is, what a wonderful story-- every child should see Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory, the original, the classic...

I've watched this movie many times and it never gets old. I have 3 boys - they are all grown up now with kids of their own. The remember this movie and remember the messages the ooompa-loompas gave to them. All of the messages got thru to them -every time they watched it. It should be shown to all kids now days - the messages and life lessons are still true today and they were when this movie came out.

Review title: BEST MOVIE OF ALL TIME, at least one of them
Review_body: This movie is phenomenal on all accounts. I haven't read any other reviews, however if any say this movie is not top of the line material, discount them immediately.To appreciate this movie you need to appreciate so much more than simply mindlessly watching television. It is immensely deep, and anyone who says otherwise is a nitwit. (see what I did there?)Naturally one can appreciate the movie for the sheer brilliant performance given by Gene Wilder. He is horrifically and terrifyingly BRILLIANT! Whether it is his ability to pull at the heartstrings of the audience from his sweet and innocent eyes, or his ability to pierce the very bottom of the audience's soul in pure terror and fright, he is amazing. He is definitely one of my favorite actors of all time. Some people claim that this movie is just plain weird, so be it. It is weird, but that doesn't mean it isn't good. I love every last bit of this movie. I also read in the trivia listed here that Leonardo Di Caprio once claimed it was one of his favorite movies, so tell that to those naysayers. My favorite scene is most likely the boat scene. I LOVE IT. Wilder is so terrifying. That he can captivate so much fear, just WOW. There are not words to describe my feelings about this movie. Further, I love the random quotes throughout the movie. The one liners that Wilder throws about on whim throughout the movie are actually references to brilliant works of literature and poetry. He quotes Shakespeare and Arthur O'Shaughnessy, just to name a few. From this movie I also gained on of my favorite poems of all times, it was an Ode written by the latter from above. "We are the music makers, and we are the dreamers of dreams, wandering by lone sea breakers and sitting by desolate streams, world-losers and world- foresakers on whom the pale moon gleams, yet we are the movers and shakers, of the world forever, it seems." AHHHH. Wondrous. I actually have that portion of the poem memorized because I love it THAT much. Also, fun fact, if you want to creep people out hard core, take a lesson from old Willy himself. Memorize random quotes and such and then at random times stop whatever it is that you are doing and peer deeply into the eyes of someone around you. Then begin reciting what you have memorized. The reactions are hilarious. Something to look for in the movie which methinks is an anachronism can be seen right about the time when Charlie gets the golden ticket. There are actually several if you look hard. First, if you see the ads behind him when he is wandering about the outside of the candy store they are clearly not the era they are going for in the film. But what is most out of place is the man standing in blue jeans and a black shirt reading a newspaper. I don't know if he was mistakenly on set, if he was supposed to be there, or what. But it is worth noting and observing. All in all it is a great film. Good for children in that they don't truly understand everything about it. Cool for adults because they can see it on a deeper level. One final remark, why did no one ever notice the man with the huge slash across his face talking to their children? For all they knew he could have been whispering sweet nothings into their ears. But at the same time I think it was done for humour reasons. I like to think of Gene Wilder and his crew sort of being like Seth Rogen, Michael Cera, Jason Segel, James Franco, and that lot. They just represent different time periods. Word.

What a great movie! Gene Wilder was awesome as Wonka, and the original movie is a kids classic. Now there is a new movie coming out directed by Tim Burton. He makes such interesting movies and is a creative director, but I wonder why he couldn't have moved forward with one of the other Wonka stories. Certainly Johnny Depp is an "odd enough" and versatile actor to play the recluse of Wonka, but would have much preferred they left Charlie & The Chocolate Factory for Wilder and let Depp play Wonka on The Great Glass Elevator. Still, will go see the new movie and see how Burton has "darkened" the Wonka character. I'm hoping it will still be a lite enough movie for younger kids, but am guessing this will not be the case. If you get a chance, check out the trailer by doing a net search for the new movie.

Review title: "A little nonsense now and then, is relished by the wisest men."
Review_body:
One of the greatest children's films ever made, full of hope and wonder. For child viewers it's a very blatant morality tale where poor behaviour has consequences. For adults there is a rich vein of humour.
They cleverly shot it in Berlin with a mix of American and British actors, which makes the story feel like it could be anywhere.
Gene Wilder puts on an unforgettably mesmerizing performance and Roy Kinnear makes a very good exasperated straight man to his zaniness.

While Tim Burton has claimed that his remake is closer to the book, it is purely superficial. Mel Stuart did add some original songs, changed the title, and swapped the nut room for the room with the golden geese, but the integrity and heart is intact. (granted that Burton did add his own subplot about wonka's childhood) Roald Dahl's books are not simply dark fantasies or absurdist romps, but are moreover sensitive and warm in a rather odd way. Dahl's conception of Willy Wonka is more reflected by Gene Wilder, who grounds himself in both worlds of fantasy and reality and moreover is warm, caring and somewhat aloof. This is something that Depp couldn't channel in his interpretation, and actually helps to cause Burton's film a breakdown. There is a quality to the original that cannot be reproduced. It is a far simpler film that doesn't try to be high and mighty. The acting is superb, the effects are simple nearly seamless, and the screenplay is dead on. This film has attained the status of a classic without trying very hard, and will not be forgotten. It needs no on screen antecedents, and I feel that the remake was made more or less to cash in on Burton's swiftly declining originality, and the fruits of the box office. Simply put, the original is far more genuine.

Review title: A touching Movie But i hate Wonka!
Review_body: I found this movie very touching until they got to the factory.(Warning Contains spoilers!) Charlie Bucket is a very poor boy who has a love for chocolate. He lives with his mum and four grandparents (of which he favours grandpa Joe) who have been in bed for 20 years. He lives in the same town as Willy Wonka's chocolate factory which hasn't been open for years. One day it was announced that Wonka will let 5 people in if they found the gold tickets. The first 4 were found by naughty greedy brats first Ourgust Gloop a greedy German boy then Vereca Salt a spoilt brat whose rich father forced his factory workers to unwrap Wonka bars till they found one. then Violet Beeruagard a gum chewer with bad manners then Mike Teevee a TV lover and a pain in the neck.Then the miracle happens Charlie finds a golden ticket and his dream comes true he and his grandpa Joe go to the factory.Oh dear then we meet Wonka a Weired seemingly friendly chocolate factory owner. though he dosen' care that Orgustus nearly drowns in his chocolate river or that violet turns into a blue berry by his dangerous products, then he doesn't cared that Vereca falls down the eggdicater or that mike Teevee shrunk by sending himself be television though all their parents were worried sick. In the end Charlie gets the chocolate factory because he was the only one left, which i was very pleased about but a definitely hate Wonka. But i was very impressed by Gene Wilders performance he played a great Wonka

OK, let's face it, this movie is an out and out classic. I know bad movie reviews are much more fun to read, but I just can't think of any thing bad to say about it. Well, except maybe the special effects, (the elevator-on-a-string) but they did OK considering it was before CGI. It could've been worse. And everything else in it kicks ass!!! Gene Wilder rocks as Willy Wonka, constantly coming out with odd quotes/comments/songs at totally random moments and just generally freaking everyone out. The songs are all brilliant(except maybe "Cheer up Charlie" which is OK in moderation but gets a little tiring after a while)I mean, come on, "Pure Imagination", "I've got a golden ticket" Verruca Salt singing "I want it now", and obviously, "The Candyman". And no matter what anyone says, I love the boat scene. i know the special effects are crap(none of them get splashed, their hair isn't even blown back!) but Gene Wilder's weird spur-of-the-moment song sends shivers down my spine. (He's the best actor EVER!!)Overall, i would say, go buy this classic movie. Now! Go on! You're not gone yet! What are you waiting for? you heard Gene Wilder's in it, right?? GO!

Review title: Just a fantastic and magical movie, but definitely made for older children.
Review_body: This is an old time great musical and fantasy movie with great moral lessons, but don't be mistaken into thinking this is a movie for little children. The extremely creepy scenes and the constant literary references makes the movie appropriate for older kids, maybe teens, and for adults looking to remember what it was like to be a kid and imagining what magical it must be like being inside a chocolate factory.P.S.- The internet meme of Grandpa Joe being a scumbag are totally true. The movie is about Charlie realizing his grandpa is a bad person.

this movie is worth a thousand Oscars because it suits all ages and it contains some of the best and most important subjects of life. it is completely covered by a substance of love, family, childhood and imagination.I recommend a movie of this to watch over and over and to have at home for all the time. not only does it keep you smiling but it brings your mood level all the way up to the clouds with no doubt. I have never gotten bored of it ad i have watched it many a time for a long time. the passion of children and making something with love is unspeakable. its a masterpiece a creation of the soul and the mind in one. it's the most original screenplay and cast and script. do not leave this undiscovered. it contains issues everyone will enjoy and on one side it is not an easy movie to understand or to grasp the concept of the whole meaningful script. i didn't really understand it much until i watched again lately after about 5 or 4 years without watching it.i absolutely love it and so will you.

The late Gene Wilder shines as Willy Wonka. The film brings the book to life.Willy Wonka was released on June 30, 1971. The film was not a big success, being the fifty-third highest- grossing film of the year in the U.S., earning just over $2.1 million on its opening weekend,although it received positive reviews from critics such as Roger Ebert, who compared it to The Wizard of Oz. But kids of today really enjoy this.

This film is an absolute masterpiece. I know that term gets thrown around a lot, but it truly is. It tells a simple story with pure imagination and love thrown into it. The characters are all so memorable, with a great cast to back them up, particularly Gene Wilder as Willy Wonka, Peter Ostrum as Charlie Bucket, and Jack Albertson as Grandpa Joe. The songs are all magnificent, my favorite being Pure Imagination. The practical effects are groundbreaking even to this day. The ending is perfect, one of the best I've seen in cinematic history, one that leaves you thinking. If you haven't seen it you're missing out. High recommendation to everyone.Oh, and before you ask, the remake is just okay, in my opinion.

This was a very cheesy film,I don't mean the food for all you cheese lovers,lol.Anyway this was terrible,It had old graphics,it didn't even have the title of the book.The actors were insane,I would rather watch ''Dumbo''.Charlie looked like a girl for petesake. I recommend the new & improved version directed by Tim Burton & composed by Danny Elfman. Johnny Depp was great and much better then Gene Wilder. Freddy Heighmore also did a better job in my opinion then the other actor who played Charlie in the 1971 version. The ompa loompa's were much better in this film. I feel they had more of a purpose in the new film,Deep Roy did a great job playing the ompa loompa's. Definitely go rent the 2005 film "Charlie & the Chocolate Factory" instead of this 1971 movie.

Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory is my favorite movie of all time! It was the first VHS tape that I purchased for myself and will be the first DVD I buy in a few weeks. But enough about me... This movie has everything you could ask for in a clean, family movie. It has hilarious comedy, a suspenseful storyline (though almost everyone knows what will happen), great special effects (for 1971), well-developed, unique characters, and of course, a story that any sweet-toothed viewer can relate to. This movie is perfect for viewers of all ages. I've watched it with wide-eyed 5-year olds, perverted teenagers (they love the Oompa Loompa scenes and the boat ride), adults, and the elderly, and all of them enjoy the flick. It is truly a classic movie, despite being underappreciated at the time of its release. Grab a handful of Gobstoppers and sit down to enjoy Willy Wonka!!

I love this film, possibly because I have a three year old who becomes totally absorbed in the story whenever he sees it. I've rediscovered the eye-popping delights of a secret world dedicated to the guilt-free invention and sampling of scrumptious chocolate and sugar confections. It's a cautionary tale of course - a concept my son has yet to grasp, bless him - warning against the evils of excess and over-indulgence and celebrating virtue and honesty. I love the three main characters - they all play their roles to perfection, particularly Gene Wilder who was just perfect casting. His Willy Wonka is, naturally, a reclusive oddball who, in the course of the factory tour, proves to be an intriguing combination of secretive, controlling, unpredictable grown-up and candid, excitable, mischievous, capricious child. Dated special-effects and appalling singing included, this film is a joy from start to finish. The saccharine ending is the icing on the cake.

Review title: The Finest Non-Animated Children's Movie Ever. Period.
Review_body: It's quirky, it's entertaining, and it involves lots and LOTS of candy and chocolate. Who can see this movie and NOT be insanely jealous of those gaining entrance into The Chocolate Room? Or giggle at Violet Beauregarde's sassiness, Veruca Salt's tantrums, or Wonka's many mind-bending one-liners? Gene Wilder is absolutely perfect as the leading role, which gives Johnny Depp EXTREMELY huge shoes to fill if a remake is indeed made. But no matter what becomes of that possibility, nothing will EVER hold a candle to this classic original. For heaven's sake -- it's like trying to remake "Gone With The Wind"!

Review title: A beautiful and fun film for people of all ages!
Review_body: After recently watching Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory for the first time in years, I was amazed at how funny I found it, even though I'm no longer the little kid who used to love it. The costuming and sets are great, and although the special effects may seem a little archaic by today's CG stuff, it's still pretty good. The children in the film play the parts to perfection, the songs and music are fun and full of life and Gene Wilder is absolutely brilliant as Willy Wonka. But my favourite part of the film - the perfect, sweet last line.

This movie is a kid's delight. Kids love eating candy and here was an opportunity for them to spend all their hard-earned money to buy chocolate bars with the expectation of finding a gold coupon (one of about 10) that would allow them into Willy Wonka's Chocolate Factory. I loved it for I was a candy freak as a child and am a pastry and sugar freak now. But I hated it for two reasons. It is like a lottery where all the children spend all their money on candybars with the expectation of finding the very few gold coupons enclosed. Alas there can be only one winner and everyone else is disappointed. Willy made a lot of money on that deal. Charlie has his high hopes of getting that very last coupon that is available as there are public announcements as coupons are found. What I didn't like about the movie is this: It is a children's movie and I don't like smoking in any movie let alone children's movies. Charlie's bed-ridden Grandpa is always smoking. In fact Charlie buys the old man tobacco with his own money that he earned on his paper route. I can see tobacco company executives wringing their hands with glee over this. On top of that the lead character, Willy Wonka, played by Gene Wilder, is seen smoking in his office near the end of the movie. Nice role-model he is. This movie is a kid's delight. Superb synthesis, for children & adults, one of those rare movies that lives up to the book. The scene that should not be missed is the boat ride & song. If the opportunity to see it in a theater should arise DO NOT PASS IT UP! Roald Dahl is one of my favorite authors & I highly recommend any & all of his books, especially "The Wonderful Story Of Henry Sugar & 6 More"(not for young children). If you know a child (or adult) who does not like to read, Mr. Dahl will change their mind.

Review title: A Classic film for All Ages
Review_body: I would have to say that Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory is one of the all time greatest films. The adults will get some of the jokes, but the kids will find more than one ways to laugh about it. When I babysit, I bring it with me and I have found that even the youngest of children were entranced by the story.Charlie is a young boy who lives very poorly with his mother and four grandparents. When one day world famous candy maker Willy Wonka sends out five golden tickets hidden in bars of chocolate. The winners will receive a life time supply of Chocolate and will be lead through a tour of the factory. With a little bit of luck and a heart of gold Charlie is taken on a journey through his imagination led by Willy Wonka. I highly recommend this film to everyone who is willing to use their imagination.

Review title: Not Just For Kids...a Movie With True Cinematic Emotion
Review_body: If you would like to watch one of the greatest and saddest moments in cinema, watch the scene in which Charlie and Grampa Joe open the second chocolate bar. When Charlie says 'I bet that golden ticket makes the chocolate taste terrible' he is summarizing every false word of consolation any poor child in history has ever heard or said. Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory is an everlasting movie, one that exudes surrealism in every frame; yet it is so human it's hard to imagine a world without little green men that make chocolate and sing morals. Please watch this movie again if you found it frightening, confusing, or dull when you were a child, it's really not for kids.

Review title: The greatest children's movie of all time
Review_body: My love affair with this movie started when I was just a child. I don't remember when I watched it for the first time, but I do know that I took it for granted for several years that this was the best children's movie I had ever seen ("Charlotte's Web" and several of the Muppet movies were up there too). Now, as an adult, I watch Wonka every few months and am simply amazed how timeless everything is about it. I know that the new Depp vehicle will be a better version of the book and Dahl's fantastic writing will come to life through Tim Burton, but I doubt if the new movie will ever take away from the magic of Gene Wilder; the acting by the five fantastic kids; and of course, the chocolate. My favorite scene has to be while Wilder is singing "Pure Imagination" in the Chocolate Room. It is timeless.

This movie is tell all of every child's dream. To not only go to what is marveled, in the movie, all over the world by each and every child who eats candy, but to WIN the place too? Hello!! Win it because you found a dollar in the gutter, amidst on being down in the dumps because you of all people really, really love WIlly Wonka candy. Then, to be put into a position to screw him over when you think you're getting the shaft, and to NOT do it because you admire and respect everything this chocolate maker does is an incredible story line. But that's not all, because you were so true to your beliefs, you now OWN the factory yourself. How awesome is this? Put that together with the line of all movie lines... "Charlie, did you hear about the boy who suddenly got everything he wanted? He lived happily ever after." Hallmark moment!!! NO matter how old you are, this movie has the storyline and sub-plots for you. Enjoy!

First off, how can't you like Wonka? I love this movie. Has great songs, good characters, the plot is solid and for the budget of this movie they did an amazing job with the sets, especially the chocolate room. Wonka was the original troll. Almost everything he said was sarcastic and I love it. Like when Veruca and her dad fall down the bad egg chute and Wonka says, "There is going to be a lot of trash today". LOL love it. This is great movie, and a must watch classic. If you don't like Wonka, well then...YOU LOSE, GOOD DAY SIR! RIP Gene.

I've seen this movie hundreds of times at various ages (ah, the magic of cable), but I never really cared for it. It was well cast, and the kids performed well. But Gene Wilder seemed bored and detached - his brilliance is really only showcased by Mel Brooks. Why were the Oompa Loompas orange? I always hated the musical interludes - they dragged on forever and felt more like filler than story information. The boat ride was just weird, and sent my five year old shaking out of the room. Too many segments didn't follow the book well enough for me. By contrast, I enjoyed Johnny Depp's version, even with the really painfully stereotypical obnoxious children and added back story on Wonka.

Review title: Wow what a movie seriously i feel like to watch this movie again n again.
Review_body: About this movie please don't miss it. It will remind u your childhood days seriously i went back to my past with this movie seriously this is something which i don't want to come out with this days and story of this movie its all childrens imagination. Please show this movie to all generations. Thank u for making this movie.

Review title: Little surprises around every corner, but nothing dangerous
Review_body: This is one of my very favorite movies.  I read "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" when I was young, but only saw this movie for the first time about 6 months ago.  I now have the DVD and watch certain classic scenes over and over again. This is also the movie that got me hooked on Gene Wilder. He's absolutely brilliant in this film.  Every movement, every glance, every line is delivered to perfection. He really plays up the wit and sarcasm, which I love.  In fact, I think all the actors are perfect for their roles.The sets are very colorful and make you wish you could just jump inside the TV and experience the chocolate factory for yourself!

Classified as a children's movie, it really has a dark edge more appropriate for adults.  Starts slowly, but I'll never forget when I first saw the main room in the chocolate factory. Spectacualr Eye Candy! The songs are good too.  Gene Wilder is great as Wonka and the child actors are good as well. I love the story of a poor boy who wins the chance of a lifetime.  The bad eggs (especially Veruca) get their comeuppance.  But I really can't explain why this is my favorite movie!  It just has this je ne sais quoi that makes it so great!

this is the worst movie I have ever seen. The set is looking so cheap, songs are crap (Mary Poppins was otherwise better), the jokes are not functioning, acting is poor. And because it's now 30 years old it has to be a classic and cult.... it's not B, it's, it's not even a Z movie, one should invent another letter for it.... I want my hour and a half of my life back!!!! Tim Burtons' version was much much better....What I have to put 10 lines of text. How could one put such stupid guidelines! I don't have anything more to say about that movie! Well yeah, the chocolate lake looks nothing like chocolate. What comes in mind is something rather not appetising.A complete flop which should have remained one.

Review title: 100% Family Entertainment from start to finish
Review_body: Fantastical books, particularly children's books, can be daunting to show on the big screen. This film is so well done, that any plot divergences can be overlooked when the overall effect is so magnificent, as it is here. Considering that beyond Gene Wilder and Roy Kinnear, this is a cast of little-knowns, it shows what a great script can do for any cast, given the belief in it. The designs are superb, both inside and outside the factory, there is almost every kind of comedy, from verbal to visual, and the dramatic device involving deception (and a certain sweet) is almost secondary to the wild adventure which Charlie Bucket undergoes. I thoroughly enjoyed this film as a child, and as an adult, it loses none of its charm. Also, the ending is not disappointing. Which perhaps means that it is a fairytale after all.

Review title: The Best Movie Gene Wilder ever did
Review_body: This movie that Gene did made me realize how much I love acting. During my senior year in high school, I got to play Willie Wonka in a play that the theatre put on. It turned out to be a big success. Everyone love it. I thank you very much Gene Wilder. Your acting inspired me to try something that I never thought I could do. I also want to mention that the songs were the best for the movie. To anyone who is reading this summary of mine, THIS MOVIE IS A MUST SEE. It is the best movie I have ever seen and still today I watch it alot.

Im not a big fan of singing and dancing. But this movie brings it out in everyone. After I got the DVD of this film, it quickly became my practice that at the end of a bad week, I'd come home on Friday, put it on, and watch the world's worries leave. I'm a great fan of escapism, and this film is the best thing I've ever found to help me achieve it. No matter what happened that week, on the weekend i can dance all day, whistling away.The scene in this movie that best sums up its effect is "Pure Imagination". Children running everywhere in a room filled with sweets - any child's dream. And that is why this film is so perfect. It shows us all our childhood dreams come true for Charlie, allows for that little while to believe it could happen to us. But more importantly this film, and especially this scene, shows us life through a child's eyes, full of wonder. If that doesn't cheer you up, there is something wrong with you.

Willy Wonka and the chocolate factory its simply Magical!! When i first saw this movie as a child i was really impressed i loved the movie since then. When you see the movie it gives you like special powers to love. I really recommend this movie to all of the IMDB members you wont regret it. By the way to bad Warnerbrothers only released the pan and scan format, ive heard many persons complain about this but to me it dosent matter i will always love and remember this movie.

Review title: There is no life I know to compare with Pure Imagination
Review_body: "You can never never doubt what no one is sure about." "So much time and so little to do, what a minute, strike that revers it." This movie is so clever with such wonderful quotes and songs. Part of you is scarred of Willy Wonka, but yet you want to be his best friend.  A wonderful movie.

Although many people found the movie great,well, I didn't and so will you.First of all if you read the book you'll probably come upon this movie and feel desperate to watch it,but don't it's a waste of time, the props are junky,the acting, oh my god,it's not even funny, it's even worse than you imagine it will be,I also hate the characters and Willy Wonka is is bad, this movie doesn't even have sounds or special effects and the music(yuck),but come on give these guys a break it's in the 70's.Heres a tip if you read the book and dying to see the movie, turn to CHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY starring Johnny Depp,this movie is funnier and so darn cool,the actors are okay and I would recommend this movie for RONALD DAHL readers.Hope this comment was useful.

A fabulous, wild ride.  I've seen it dozens of times and still enjoy every moment.  A morals lesson, an honesty lesson.  It's good, wholesome entertainment for children and adults alike.  This happens to be my favorite movie of ALL time.

Review title: A good movie, but not really true to the book.
Review_body: I was born 6 years after the movie was made. I read the book numerous of times throughout my childhood and didn't see the movie until I was 24. Knowing the book by heart I got pretty disappointed. It didn't quite follow it, and I don't know why. It's basically a very uncomplicated and short book that easily could have turned into a movie. And I just can't see why they have turned Willy Wonka from a strange but eccentric man (book) to a rambling nutcase (movie).But still. If you haven't read the book I can strongly recommend that you see this movie. A movie about dreams coming true, worlds that just exist in your imagination (and on film) and great humour. But for the real deal: Read the book. It's one of Roald Dahls best and don't forget to catch the second book (yes, there is two of them)

Review title: Willy, you had me at "Pure Imagination"!
Review_body: I think it's pretty safe to say that Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory is a timeless classic. Not only does it feature a great plot, fantastic acting and show how movies don't have to be full of computer animation to be good, but it also features some of the best music I have ever heard in a movie.I still remember, almost as clearly as if it were yesterday, the remarkable thing the movie did to me the first time I watched it: It completely changed my mind about musicals! I was about 10 years old when I first sat down and watched the movie. Like a lot of kids, I didn't much care for musical numbers in movies. So when the music for "Pure Imagination" started playing, I thought, "Oh great, a musical number!" I was just about to press the fast-forward button when Willy Wonka (Gene Wilder) began singing.Within about two seconds, I was completely mesmerized! I didn't think I had ever heard such a beautiful song in my life, nor had I heard too many singing voices that were as beautiful as Willy's. It felt like he was singing that song as much to me as he was to the kids and parents in the movie! That song certainly captured MY imagination, and after hearing it for the first time, I saw musicals in a whole new light.I may be grown now, but I still like the movie every bit as much as I did as a ten-year-old....and I will always have a special spot in my heart for "Pure Imagination" the song that convinced me that musicals can be some of the best movies out there!

Review title: How anyone can prefer the new film is beyond me...
Review_body: This is in my opinion the greatest musical of all time and I am sure that I am not the only person that thinks this. Pure Imagination is a classic, so is Candyman, cheer up Charlie even I want it now is brilliant. It is wonderful, magical and there is no other film like it, including the new film. I would give the new one 2 out of 10 as it is a disgrace to the old version. Just because Roald Dahl didn't like this film it does not mean he would like that one. Gene Wilders performance is spectacular. This is the classic and it can't be beaten by any crappy performance by any actor no matter how famous. Each song is the equivalent (sorry for spelling!) of the best song in any other musical.

Review title: One of the Best? Wrong. The best.
Review_body: It's a crazy movie with even crazier characters.  And that alone makes it more realistic than most of us realize.  We all have some aspect of each of these characters inside us.  Both the greedy kids and their equally greedy parents are unfortunately just like us.  However, there is hope for our world because inside each of us is a bit of the virtuous Charlie, struggling to succeed.But Willy Wonka is the truly magical character of this movie.  He has the creative mind and flamboyant nature that we all have, but rarely show.  He lives in a paradise of his own creation.  He lets his imagination and desires dictate what he does, without succumbing to the sin of greed.But this is all subtly delivered to you.  You don't have to analyze this movie to enjoy it.  You have so many fantastic characters that parallel the school teachers, news reporters, psychologists, and scientists of the world to laugh at again and again.It's a movie of two halves: The first is the outside world where five golden tickets are found.  The second is the fantasy world of the Chocolate Factory where imagination comes to life.  What this movie does so well is combine the two worlds, suggesting we add more fantasy and creativity to our repetitve and greedy everyday lives.  Use your mind to warm the world up, so you can get out of bed without worrying about a cold floor.

Review title: If you are wise you will listen to me
Review_body: Quite simply the greatest film ever.  What it may lack in technical expertise (don't forget, it was made in 1971) it makes up for with a wonderful story, superb script and bedazzling performances from all.Ignore any negative comments on here about this film so far.  It is a moral tale showing what happens if you do not pay attention, eat too much, pick up bad habits, are spoilt or watch too much TV (too much tv apparently gives you a pain in the neck and an IQ of 3!).  It champions innocence, honesty and childhood dreams.  As Wonka says "I couldn't leave it to an adult, they would change things".  The factory is a place where anything can (and does) happen.If you've become hardened and desensitised to today's fodder, transport yourself back to your childhood via this film and recapture your glorious youth.Infinitely watchable, wonderful characters - four absolutely beastly children, one underdog; one manic chocolate maker and a host of Oompah Loompahs which were rescued from snozzwangers and vermicious kernids! What more could anyone want.Never forget that "We are the music makers and we are the dreamers of dreams."

Review title: My review for my Film Analysis and Exploration class
Review_body: Calling a movie your all time favorite is quite a task. I believe I was around seven years old when I first watched Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory. Ever since that first viewing, I have been in love with the film and its incredible diegesis. Though the film all together is a wonderful timeless piece, for the purpose of my review I want to start when the winners of the golden tickets enter the factory with their parents. As they travel along the many rooms, corridors, tunnels, and halls of the factory, the viewer learns more about each individual child and, more importantly, what is characteristically wrong with them and their parents. Though Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory captures the viewer through Gene Wilder's quirky character and the sensory delightfulness of the factory, one of the most important things the viewer takes away from this film are morals. More specifically, to be polite, selfless, kind, respectful everything that our parents are suppose to teach us and are deemed desirable by society. What makes this message so universal is the fact that not only is it meant for children but adults as well. The viewer learns these "lessons" from all of the children as well as their parents, who are partly if not entirely to blame for their behavior. The first child to be taken away is Augustus Gloop, a fat little boy who falls into the chocolate river. Even though Willy Wonka tells Augustus to stay away from the river, the boy is disobedient and even falls in and gets sucked up into a pipe. His fault is gluttony. Three other children all share similar fates, all representing an imperfection in society. The second child, Veruca Salt, is terribly spoiled by her father and demands to have one of the golden egg laying geese inside the factory. She attempts to get one and is deemed a "bad egg" and sent down a chute, followed by her father. She is, of course, greed. The two other children personify stubbornness and rudeness and are both punished for it; one by becoming a human blueberry, the other, turned into a micro-sized version of himself. The protagonist of the film, Charlie, is the only child left at the end of the factory tour. However, since he is only human, him and his grandfather (the only respectable parental figure besides, perhaps, Wonka himself) drink a fizzy soda that makes the both of them float up to the ceiling. Unlike the other participants, their predicament is only temporary. Even so, Willy Wonka is displeased with them and tells them to leave. Being obedient, regretful, and respectful, they exit the factory. Only through their act of humility does Wonka present them with the ultimate prize, the factory itself. This sends an obvious message to the viewer of what attributes are right and which ones are wrong.It was only recently that I realized Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory was made in 1971. I knew it was an old movie, but I was shocked to find out it is over forty years old. Once the characters enter the factory, time seems to stop. There is nothing dated in the factory, save for the television, and the characters themselves don't necessarily give away a time period. These elements, along with the very universal message the film is sending, make it sincerely timeless. People in twenty years from today can watch this movie and still take away from it, young and old.

Review title: A film not without flaws, but fantastic nonetheless
Review_body: The film "Willy Wonka and the Chocalate Factory" has divided critics and moviegoers alike since it was first released. Doubtless there are some who would not enjoy this movie, as with any movie, but it is certainly among the best kids movies ever made, that is also enjoyable for adults. The film deals with a boys journey through the chocolate factory of the eccentric Mr Willy Wonka. It is an adaptation of a novel by acclaimed children's author Roald Dahl, and as such, the plot is whimsical and engrossing. I have no complaints with the plot, except for Charlie visiting his mother at the laundry, an intrusive device to allow the inclusion of a song that is boring at best. The song was supposed to give some emotional impact, and give us a look into the relationship between Charlie and his mother. The only thing this achieves, is to leave the viewer wondering why Charlie did not even consider asking his mother to accompany him to the chocolate factory, instead of his bedridden (and lazy) grandfather. Aside from this small complaint, I believe the plot is excellent.The casting of the film is superb, leading to some great acting. The obvious standout is Mr Gene Wilder, who gives the performance of his lifetime as Willy Wonka. He is charming, eccentric, dark and a little bit scary. Of course no small amount of this is due to a script that gives him some great lines. Still, we must take nothing away from Gene Wilder, who gives a performance that most actors would give their right arms to equal. Other characters are also memorable, such as; Charlie's teacher, Veruca, Veruca's father, Violet, Mr Slugworth and the candy store owner. All of the actors playing these parts give exceptional performances. In regards to the characters, the only real complaint is Charlie himself. He is noticeably the weakest link in the chain. This is not entirely the actors fault, though he must shoulder some of the blame. The character, as written, is weak. He is given nothing memorable to say or do. He seems to be your classic goody-two-shoes (despite the "fizzy lifting drink" episode, obviously added to try and combat this problem). Charlie is supposed to be the "straight" character, in that he is the normal one. This is to give the other characters someone to "bounce off" if you will. However this idea was carried much to far, to the detriment of the film. Such is the problem that every second Charlie is on screen, we wish for the camera to focus on a different character. Other than this, the characters, and acting, are great.It may seem that this review is rather critical given the rating (10/10). This rating was given in response to the amount of enjoyment that one can get from watching this film. The movie is flawed, yet it is a great movie nonetheless. No movie is perfect, despite what some fans might say. But a great movie is enjoyable in spite of its flaws. This is a must see movie. Please, before seeing the new Tim Burton version, watch Mel Stuart's version, as it is one of the great films.

Review title: The Bookers ( Texas) Most Watched Movie!!!
Review_body: Love it ... Wonderful... Life Lessons ... Teaches Morals and Values!!!

Most excellent works in the arts are seen and enjoyed at a variety of "levels." That is true of this movie in general and of Gene Wilder in specific.Wilder has been known in the circles of movie creators as a creative genius for many years. Here, his acting ability showcases that genius. To be sure, at the level of good fun for kids and Moms and Dads, he comes through. But writers must have loved his work. Watch for the "look" in his eyes. You will see "changes" in them as he speaks or as he listens to the kids. Those unheard, barely seen changes can be read many ways. And that is the genius. They put more into the lines than the words themselves.Art should be clearly and quickly understood. It should also be the tool used to make us wonder a bit. Think a little. Or find meaning we didn't see at first look. In this movie, Gene Wilder's almost imperceptible nuances speak volumes.

Having seen this as a 10 year old, I can understand how this film still brings me a great sense of warmth. Being a HUGE fan of chocolate, I was instantly drawn to the theater that day. Wonka bars were being sold by the fistfuls at the concession stand. Having procured my bounty. I stepped in, soon to be enveloped in pure cinematic magic. I was not disappointed, for then I became completely immersed in the films warm, chocolate blanket. I just saw this on TV a few days ago, and was (almost) equally mesmerized by the imagery. Undoubtedly Gene Wilder's most endearing role. If any of you didn't get choked up when Charlie unwraps the golden ticket, Sorry, you're dead already. I have to give it a 10

Viewing Willy Wonka and the Chocolate factory as a child and as a young adult I appreciated it's whimsical appearance and it's fantastic story. Not until recently did I discover the religious symbolism that runs throughout the film. I've never read the book which the film was based upon so I can't say if there are any similarities regarding religious symbolism in the book. The Religious spin: Wonka represents God The Chocolate factory represents Heaven or Eden Slugworth represents the Devil The everlasting gobstopper represents the soul The story essentially tells the tale of how mankind is offered the opportunity (the golden ticket) to reap Heaven (Chocolate factory). The opportunities are few in a world littered with corruption. The adults of the world are portrayed as cynical, untrusting or untrustworthy. The golden tickets find their way into the hands of children. Charlie, the protagonist of the story, is shown to be the kindest and most humble. Upon receiving their tickets the children are immediately confronted by Slugworth (the Devil) who whispers temptation into their ears. The first impression we are provided of the reclusive Wonka (God) is that of a prankster, as he shyly limps out only to tumble forward evoking both shock and delight. Throughout the film the Wonka character expresses a gamut of emotions to the point of knowing what he is like but not understanding him. He's both structured and chaotic. Upon entering the factory the guests are provided rules (some visible while others are practically invisible). The guests are instructed to sign that they will obey the rules (Symbolic of Adam and Eve). During the story each of the children fall prey to a number of the deadly sins; Augustus (gluttony), Veruca (greed), Violet (envy/vanity), Charlie (envy), and Mike (vanity). In each case the sin brings shame and disastrous results. One of the most famous quotable lines from the film is the Wonka statement,'We are the music makers. We are the dreamers of dreams'. Wonka (God) is stating 1. The relationship between He (God) and his guests (humans) exists when expressing We and that they each share the ability to create. And, 2. that the infinite is possible. With Wonka (God) all things are possible.Throughout the story appear the Oompa Loompas (Angels) who do the bidding of Wonka and provide sage advice for those who've fallen prey to sin. At one point in the story the children are each offered Wonka's greatest invention, the Everlasting Gobstopper. He informs them that this special treat will last forever and instructs them that it can never land in the hands of Slugworth (Devil). The children and their parents eye one another expressing their understanding of it's significance and of Slugworth's desire for it. In the end only Charlie and his Uncle remain at the conclusion of the tour. Wonka shows them the door and turns away to go about his business. Confused, they inquire about the chocolate and they're rebuffed by Wonka who scolds them for disobeying the rules. At this point Wonka (God) appears cold and distant. Charlie's Uncle, experienced to the corruption of the world (and victim of his own slothfulness), suggests to Charlie that they deal with Slugworth. Unswayed, Charlie, expressing remorse for his actions, offers the Everlasting Gobstopper (Soul) back to Wonka. Wonka turns to Charlie with a look of gratefulness and forgiveness. He tells Charlie that he did it. He passed the test. He returned the Gobstopper without letting it fall into the hands of Slugworth. Moments later, Slugworth enters the room. At first Charlie and his Uncle are taken aback by his presence, but, they are informed that Slugworth actually works for Wonka. The ominous presence previously embodied by Slugworth dissolves as he provides them with a congratulatory smile. In the final climax Charlie, having received the Chocolate Factory, takes a ride with Wonka up into the heavens. Much can be derived from the symbolic nature of the film and what it potentially is suggesting. Most notably the idea that the Devil actually works for God for the purpose of providing man with temptation in order to test his/her trustworthiness. To some that conclusion might appear to place man at a disadvantage. But, certainly not more so than what original man (Adam and Eve) had to face. Mankind still has free will. The Slugworth character (Devil) can be perceived much the same as a tool, albeit a dangerous one. A tool that enables men to act out poor choices. Similar to the adage that guns don't kill people, people kill people. The tool in the wrong hands can be a dangerous weapon but if it's ignored it's harmless. What I found most satisfactory about the potential symbolic nature of the film was that beneath it's whimsical appearance and fantastic story lie a moralistic teaching. It is a story meant to be seen by children and beyond entertaining them provide them lessons (some visible and some practically invisible) on how they should conduct themselves. And, potentially save themselves. I don't suspect that the soon to be released remake, directed by Tim Burton, will provide such lessons. The last and most intriguing question that I have regarding the Religious spin of Willy Wonka and the Chocolate factory is by who's design does it occur. Was it the author of the book? The screenwriter? The director? Or, by some other providence??

Review title: "Traveling in a world of my creation"
Review_body: When I sit down to watch a movie I want to be transported someplace else and I want to walk away feeling SOMETHING. When I sat down to watch 'Willy Wonka and The Chocolate Factory' (after many years of not seeing it) I still loved it, I still felt happy at the end and I still believed that there was that golden ticket out there for the taking. The viewer is carried away into a world where good is rewarded and evil is punished (or sent down a garbage chute!). In the end you walk away feeling that good begets good and all is right in the world...if only through the course of the film.Even though the film was made in 1971 it is not dated and the effects hold up. Gene Wilder plays a quirky chocolatier who randomly slips into the erratic but guides five children into a world of pure imagination. His performance is infallible and unfaltering. Along the way the viewer is able to see what behavior is unacceptable, thanks to the Oompa Loompa's musical morality. The film does leave some questions unanswered. The most glaring being where are Charlie's parents? If you as the viewer can dismiss reality and all logical explanation for just a few hours...you're in for a wild ride.The sign of a "classic" film is one that holds up through time. This movie is perfect for families needing a night's entertainment. The same is true for adults wanting to recapture the first time they stepped through the doors of the mystical factory, golden ticket in hand. David Seltzer was able to take the basic premise of Roald Dahl's book and create a timeless screenplay that transcends the years. He may have digressed but the end result is a movie that many generations can view and still enjoy with bright-eyed innocence.

Like most other commentators here, I too am a long term fan of this classic, primarily because of of its attendant virtuoso performance from Gene Wilder, as well as its super-charged Technicolour treatment of the subtly unsettling source material.It is here we find the dichotomy of Wonka: is he really a benevolent eccentric, or does this surreal exterior mask something more sinister? Who knows? That the film itself manages to neatly sidestep the more moralistic overtones of Dahl's book is testament to its innate sense of wonder and purpose.So, for kids of all ages, this is 'scrumdiddleumptious', and one can only hope Burton's latest take on the story lives up to it's predecessor.

Although the film deviates from the book, it is a wonderful story. Willy Wonka, played by Gene Wilder, is a very quirky, unusual character with a sweet tooth and an interesting way of teaching moral lessons. The film is colorful and lively and it definitely captures the imagination. There were a few moments in the movie that were disturbingly weird like the part when the characters took the boat down the chocolate river through the tunnel. The pictures on the tunnel wall and the almost psychotic look in Gene Wilder's eyes added a level of weird that interrupted the flow of the movie. But overall I thought that the film was enjoyable. I loved the characters and the vibrant colors and I think that a better film couldn't have been made, especially for that time.(Eastern Michigan University)

Director Mel Stuart's Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory is an overrated tale
of a rags to riches story that fails at bringing up the true disparaging nature of class
discrimination between the brats and the Buckets. Though not all the children are of
the spoiled nature, they are all somewhat entitled but not in a meaningful and well-
developed way that would show off a different side to the characters that will display
more of the complex nature of the class difference more than simple character types
with one gimmick. How the Buckets are portrayed are also heavily distorted as their
lower-class status is reduced to a nature vs nurture philosophy that makes Charlie
inherently kind hearted because of his up-bringing but not through specific events
which makes it completely cheap and undeserved.

I have grown up loving this magical film. As a child I would look forward to watching it every Christmas or Easter on TV! I now have a 4 year old daughter and she is as in love with 'Willy Wonka' as I am! Thankfully we have it on video and can watch it whenever we like and not have to rely on it coming on TV. Although when it does come on TV we will still rush to watch it anyway!!! For it's time it is so cleverly filmed and the songs i.e. The Candyman are catchy songs that you remember - they make you feel happy!My daughter's favourite bit is when the Oopma Loompas come on! She absolutely loves them and goes around singing "Oompa Oompa ooobidy Odo I've got another puzzle for you"! The film is almost 30 years before my daughter's time and yet she and her friends find this lovely film as magical as my generation did. It isn't dated and the colours in it are amazing!I have always loved Gene Wilder in all of his films and believe that he is truly brilliant as the wonderful 'Willy Wonka'!It is a wonderful feel good film that you can enjoy with all the family and I would recommend it on behalf of myself and my daughter!
